description: Circa 1750, in the sense of the dance, from French cotillon (“petticoat”), extended to the dance because of the distinctive lift of dress revealing the petticoat, from cotte (“dress”) + -illon (diminutive). Said to derive from the then-popular song Ma commère, quand je danse, mon cotillion va-t-il bien.

entries.meaning: (dance) A bold dance performed in groups of eight where women lift their skirts to display their ankles. [from 1766]
(US) Ellipsis of cotillion ball.; a coming-of-age party meant to present girls newly transitioned into womanhood to the community for courtship. [from 1898]
(textiles) A kind of woollen material for women's skirts.

verbs.description: cotillion (third-person singular simple present cotillions, present participle cotillioning, simple past and past participle cotillioned)
